messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 44 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On the Discrete Fr√©chet Distance in a Graph1footnote 11footnote 1Supported by the Hausdorff Center for Mathematics (DFG grant number EXC 2047) and Independent Research Fund Denmark grant 2020-2023 (9131-00044B) ‚ÄúDynamic Network Analysis‚Äù

Paper Abstract: Abstract The Fr√©chet distance is a well-studied similarity measure between curves that is widely used throughout computer science. Motivated by applications where curves stem from paths and walks on an underlying graph (such as a road network), we define and study the Fr√©chet distance for paths and walks on graphs. When provided with a distance oracle of Gùê∫G with O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1) query time, the classical quadratic-time dynamic program can compute the Fr√©chet distance between two walks PùëÉP and QùëÑQ in a graph Gùê∫G in O‚Äã(|P|‚ãÖ|Q|)ùëÇ‚ãÖùëÉùëÑO(|P|\cdot|Q|) time. We show that there are situations where the graph structure helps with computing Fr√©chet distance: when the graph Gùê∫G is planar, we apply existing (approximate) distance oracles to compute a (1+Œµ)1ùúÄ(1+\varepsilon)-approximation of the Fr√©chet distance between any shortest path PùëÉP and any walk QùëÑQ in O‚Äã(|G|‚Äãlog‚Å°|G|/Œµ+|P|+|Q|Œµ)ùëÇùê∫ùê∫ùúÄùëÉùëÑùúÄO(|G|\log|G|/\sqrt{\varepsilon}+|P|+\frac{|Q|}{\varepsilon}) time. We generalise this result to near-shortest paths, i.e. Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa-straight paths, as we show how to compute a (1+Œµ)1ùúÄ(1+\varepsilon)-approximation between a Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa-straight path PùëÉP and any walk QùëÑQ in O‚Äã(|G|‚Äãlog‚Å°|G|/Œµ+|P|+Œ∫‚Äã|Q|Œµ)ùëÇùê∫ùê∫ùúÄùëÉùúÖùëÑùúÄO(|G|\log|G|/\sqrt{\varepsilon}+|P|+\frac{\kappa|Q|}{\varepsilon}) time. Our algorithmic results hold for both the strong and the weak discrete Fr√©chet distance over the shortest path metric in Gùê∫G. Finally, we show that additional assumptions on the input, such as our assumption on path straightness, are indeed necessary to obtain truly subquadratic running time. We provide a conditional lower bound showing that the Fr√©chet distance, or even its 1.011.011.01-approximation, between arbitrary paths in a weighted planar graph cannot be computed in O‚Äã((|P|‚ãÖ|Q|)1‚àíŒ¥)ùëÇsuperscript‚ãÖùëÉùëÑ1ùõøO((|P|\cdot|Q|)^{1-\delta}) time for any Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0 unless the Orthogonal Vector Hypothesis fails. For walks, this lower bound holds even when Gùê∫G is planar, unit-weight and has O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1) vertices.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 44 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 44"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Popular conjectures imply strong lower bounds for dynamic problems",
        "Computing the Fr√©chet distance between two polygonal curves",
        "Comparison of distance measures for planar curves",
        "Fr√©chet distance for curves, revisited",
        "Strategic air traffic planning with Fr√©chet distance aggregation and rerouting",
        "On map-matching vehicle tracking data",
        "Why walking the dog takes time: Frechet distance has no strongly subquadratic algorithms unless seth fails",
        "Improved approximation for Fr√©chet distance on c-packed curves matching conditional lower bounds",
        "Approximability of the discrete Fr√©chet distance",
        "Clustering trajectories for map construction",
        "Four soviets walk the dog: Improved bounds for computing the Fr√©chet distance",
        "Exact algorithms for partial curve matching via the Fr√©chet distance",
        "Seth says: Weak Fr√©chet distance is faster, but only if it is continuous and in one dimension",
        "Group diagrams for representing trajectories",
        "Homotopic Fr√©chet distance between curves or, walking your dog in the woods in polynomial time",
        "An improved approximation algorithm for the discrete Fr√©chet distance",
        "Almost optimal distance oracles for planar graphs",
        "Fast and compact exact distance oracle for planar graphs",
        "Approximating the (continuous) Fr√©chet distance",
        "A new merging process for data integration based on the discrete Fr√©chet distance",
        "A note on two problems in connexion with graphs",
        "Jaywalking your dog: computing the Fr√©chet distance with shortcuts",
        "Approximating the Fr√©chet distance for realistic curves in near linear time",
        "Computing discrete Fr√©chet distance",
        "Constant query time (1+ŒµùúÄ\\varepsilon)-approximate distance oracle for planar graphs",
        "Fast Fr√©chet distance between curves with long edges",
        "Geodesic Fr√©chet distance inside a simple polygon",
        "Protein structure‚Äìstructure alignment with discrete Fr√©chet distance",
        "Preprocessing an undirected planar network to enable fast approximate distance queries",
        "Multiple-source shortest paths in planar graphs",
        "Visual analytics of delays and interaction in movement data",
        "Planar distance oracles with better time-space tradeoffs",
        "Fr√©chet distance with speed limits",
        "Coastline matching process based on the discrete Fr√©chet distance",
        "Lectures on discrete geometry, volume 212",
        "Deterministic constructions of approximate distance oracles and spanners",
        "Vehicle trajectory similarity: Models, methods, and applications",
        "Fr√©chet distance based approach for searching online handwritten documents",
        "A survey of trajectory distance measures and performance evaluation",
        "Compact oracles for reachability and approximate distances in planar digraphs",
        "Approximate distance oracles",
        "A new algorithm for optimal 2-constraint satisfaction and its implications",
        "Approximate distance oracles with improved query time",
        "Distributed trajectory similarity search"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 44 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On the Discrete Fr√©chet Distance in a Graph1footnote 11footnote 1Supported by the Hausdorff Center for Mathematics (DFG grant number EXC 2047) and Independent Research Fund Denmark grant 2020-2023 (9131-00044B) ‚ÄúDynamic Network Analysis‚Äù, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
